title: Intercession of the Saints
intro: Hypothesis: The saints in Heaven pray for people on earth.

evidence.head: The Vision of Onias and Jeremiah
evidence.short: Judas Maccabeus had a vision of the late high priest Onias praying for the Jews, and the prophet Jeremiah giving Judas a sword.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this illustrates the intercession of the saints already in the Old Testament.

Critics argue that this is a vision, so it may not be literally true. Also, 2 Maccabees is not in the Jewish canon of Scripture, so some critics feel it is less authoritative, if at all.

bible.text: 12The vision of that dream was this: Onias, he who had been high priest, a noble and good man, modest in bearing, yet gentle in manner and well-spoken, and trained from a child in all points of virtue, with outstretched hands invoking blessings on the whole body of the Jews. 13Then he saw a man appear, of venerable age and exceeding glory, and the dignity around him was wonderful and most majestic. 14Onias answered and said, “This is the lover of the kindred, he who prays much for the people and the holy city: Jeremiah the prophet of God. 15Jeremiah stretched out his right hand and delivered to Judas a gold sword, and in giving it addressed him thus: 16“Take this holy sword, a gift from God, with which you shall strike down the adversaries.”

evidence.head: Angels Pray for People
evidence.short: There are several examples of angels interceding for people in the Bible, sometimes by praying themselves, and sometimes by presenting people's prayers to God.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this suggests people in Heaven can also intercede, especially because Jesus says people will be "like the angels in Heaven" at the resurrection, which might mean they can perform many of the same tasks in Heaven.

Critics argue that Jesus is talking specifically about marriage in that passage, so not getting married might be the only thing people will have in common with angels.

bible.text: 23On that day Sadducees (those who say that there is no resurrection) came to him. They asked him, 24saying, “Teacher, Moses said, ‘If a man dies, having no children, his brother shall marry his wife and raise up offspring for his brother.’ 25Now there were with us seven brothers. The first married and died, and having no offspring left his wife to his brother. 26In the same way, the second also, and the third, to the seventh. 27After them all, the woman died. 28In the resurrection therefore, whose wife will she be of the seven? For they all had her.” 29But Jesus answered them, “You are mistaken, not knowing the Scriptures, nor the power of God. 30For in the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like God’s angels in heaven. 31But concerning the resurrection of the dead, haven’t you read that which was spoken to you by God, saying, 32‘I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob’? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living.” 33When the multitudes heard it, they were astonished at his teaching. 34But the Pharisees, when they heard that he had silenced the Sadducees, gathered themselves together.
12Then YHWH’s angel replied, “O YHWH of Armies, how long will you not have mercy on Jerusalem and on the cities of Judah, against which you have had indignation these seventy years?”

8Now when he had taken the book, the four living creatures and the twenty-four elders fell down before the Lamb, each one having a harp, and golden bowls full of incense, which are the prayers of the saints.

3Another angel came and stood over the altar, having a golden censer. Much incense was given to him, that he should add it to the prayers of all the saints on the golden altar which was before the throne. 4The smoke of the incense, with the prayers of the saints, went up before God out of the angel’s hand.
11For he will put his angels in charge of you, to guard you in all your ways. 12They will bear you up in their hands, so that you won’t dash your foot against a stone.
10See that you don’t despise one of these little ones, for I tell you that in heaven their angels always see the face of my Father who is in heaven.
15They said to her, “You are crazy!” But she insisted that it was so. They said, “It is his angel.”

evidence.head: Martyrs and the Altar In Heaven
evidence.short: John's vision includes martyrs in Heaven asking God to avenge them.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this shows human saints in Heaven praying to God, and that it would be reasonable to believe that they also pray for those on earth.

Critics caution that this is a vision and may not be literally how things work. Also, the prayers are for vengeance on their own behalf, so it could be a literary device or a symbolic way to express their status as martyrs.

bible.text: 9When he opened the fifth seal, I saw underneath the altar the souls of those who had been killed for the Word of God, and for the testimony of the Lamb which they had. 10They cried with a loud voice, saying, “How long, Master, the holy and true, until you judge and avenge our blood on those who dwell on the earth?” 11A long white robe was given to each of them. They were told that they should rest yet for a while, until their fellow servants and their brothers, who would also be killed even as they were, should complete their course.

bible.summary: Revelation 7:13–15, 8:3–4 (Angels present the prayers of the saints)
bible.text: 13One of the elders answered, saying to me, “These who are arrayed in the white robes, who are they, and where did they come from?” 14I told him, “My lord, you know.” He said to me, “These are those who came out of the great suffering. They washed their robes and made them white in the Lamb’s blood. 15Therefore they are before the throne of God, and they serve him day and night in his temple. He who sits on the throne will spread his tabernacle over them. 8:3Another angel came and stood over the altar, having a golden censer. Much incense was given to him, that he should add it to the prayers of all the saints on the golden altar which was before the throne. 4The smoke of the incense, with the prayers of the saints, went up before God out of the angel’s hand.

evidence.head: Pray for Each Other
evidence.short: Christians are instructed to pray for each other.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that there is no reason to think that those in Heaven would stop following this command.

Critics caution that we don't know what people actually do in Heaven, so this is speculative.

bible.text: 16Confess your sins to one another and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The insistent prayer of a righteous person is powerfully effective.

evidence.head: Church Fathers In Support
evidence.short: Several Church Fathers affirm the intercession of the saints.
evidence.details:
Proponents argue that this shows the belief that saints intercede for those on earth to be widespread early on.

Critics point out that it isn't mentioned all that often, so it may not have been an important belief to combat or an important teaching to deny.

ancient.author: Origen
ancient.text: "But these pray along with those who genuinely pray—not only the high priest but also the angels (...) and also the souls of the saints already at rest."

ancient.author: St. Cyprian of Carthage
ancient.text: "Let us relieve burdens and afflictions by mutual love, that if any one of us, by the swiftness of divine condescension, shall go hence the first, our love may continue in the presence of the Lord, and our prayers for our brethren and sisters not cease in the presence of the Father's mercy."

evidence.head: One Mediator
evidence.short: St. Paul writes to Timothy that there is one God and one mediator, the man Jesus Christ.
evidence.details:
Critics argue that this indicates that Jesus is the one who intercedes for us.

Proponents object that Jesus mediates the New Covenant, but St. Paul still instructs us to pray for each other in the same paragraph. Also, the Holy Spirit and angels are said to pray for us as well.

bible.text: 1I exhort therefore, first of all, that petitions, prayers, intercessions, and givings of thanks be made for all men, 2for kings and all who are in high places, that we may lead a tranquil and quiet life in all godliness and reverence. 3For this is good and acceptable in the sight of God our Savior, 4who desires all people to be saved and come to full knowledge of the truth. 5For there is one God and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus, 6who gave himself as a ransom for all, the testimony at the proper time, 7to which I was appointed a preacher and an apostle—I am telling the truth in Christ, not lying—a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and truth.
